\section{Spinons and visons as edge modes}
We try to answer these questions from a different point of view, considering Maxwell theory as emerging from some underlying spin system, when the system is in the so-called quantum spin liquid phase~\cite{Anderson:1987}. This is essentially a special ``liquid'' phase with $S=1/2$ spins as fundamental degrees of freedom. The spin system possesses $SU(2)$ symmetry, which breaks down to $U(1)$ due to some constraints. Emergence of $U(1)$ gauge dynamics could be seen in various ways, which usually employ the ``slave-particle'' , or ``parton'', construction. Typical ways involve parameterizing the spin with Abrikosov fermions or Schwinger bosons~(see, e.g., \cite{Wen2004,Lee:2006zzc,Fradkin2013} and references therein). The appearance of the gauge structure is manifest in the quantum rotor model~\cite{Wen2004,Hermele2004,Levin:2005vf,Savary2011}.

The underlying mechanism for emergence of the massless photons is proposed to be string-net condensation~\cite{Levin:2004mi}.


Sting-net condensation also provides a nice physical picture for the calculation of entanglement entropy. For the $U(1)$ case it is simply closed-string condensation. In some parameter regime of the spin system, the closed electric strings~(electric flux lines) have an almost vanishing tension and therefore proliferate rapidly. The only low-energy excitation is the massless photon, arising from the fluctuation of the closed strings. Only at very high energy, the open strings can be excited, with the endpoints carrying electric charges. So these real excitations will not be present in our calculation of the entanglement entropy of the electromagnetic field. However, when we decompose the full system into two subsystems, some of the close strings will be cut into open ones. Due to the condensation, the string part of the open strings are indistinguishable from the local closed ones in a subsystem. The endpoints act as effective charge excitations on the entangling surface. In particular, with such virtual charge excitations the total Hilbert space is factorizable, since the original microscopic system is local. So the calculation of the entanglement entropy is straightforward. As a result, the entanglement entropy will be clearly separated into two parts, the bulk gauge contributions and the edge particle contributions. Additional arguments for such a separation are shown in~\cite{Pretko:2015zva}. One may expect such a picture also applies to the magnetic excitations.

The gauge part is cleanly extracted from the local thermal analyses~\cite{Dowker:2010bu} and the duality~\cite{Casini:2015dsg}.

One may notice that the identification of spinons and visons could be equally well used in the toric code model~\cite{Kitaev:1997wr} and the general string-net models~\cite{Levin:2004mi}. While electric-magnetic duality is exact in these discrete models, for $U(1)$ theory it is broken by the compactness of the gauge potential in the microscopic description. As a result, the spinon and vison contribute differently to the universal term of the entanglement entropy.


\section{Discussion}
In the paper we have tried to understand the entanglement structure of electromagnetic field from the emergent point of view. We propose that the edge modes on the entangling surface could be identified as the virtual spinon/vison excitations, depending on the center of operator algebra. When the entangling surface is $2D$, these edge modes are proposed to be described by some specific CFTs. This seems to give a natural explanation of the difference on logarithmic coefficients of the entanglement entropy. Notice that such an understanding is closely related to the proposal in~\cite{Harlow:2015lma}.

There are many questions related to the present framework. The first is to find a direct calculation of the entanglement entropy in the magnetic center, to confirm the result here by counting the vison contribution. Another is to impose the charge-neutral condition on the entangling surface, and deduce the entropy deficit. This may be accomplished by combining our framework with recent progress made in~\cite{Pretko:2015zva}. We hope to address these and other questions in the future.
